title: PE Daily: Senate Critics Blast PE | Revised Bill Could Change Chapter 11 Cases | Banner Ridge Banks $1 Billion
text:
Today's Top Stories

At a Senate hearing Wednesday, private-equity critics denounced what they characterized as buyout managers' abusive practices, as some Democratic lawmakers seek to rein in the rapidly growing industry, Chris Cumming writes for WSJ Pro Private Equity. Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D., Mass.) led the hearing of the U.S. Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, at which workers, an academic and a state treasurer loosed volleys of criticism against private-equity managers and asked lawmakers to increase federal oversight of them.

The revised version of Ms. Warren's Stop Wall Street Looting Act includes a proposed measure that would empower creditors in chapter 11 cases to pursue allegations of self-dealing by private-equity owners, rights that currently lie with corporate directors selected by those investment firms, Alexander Saeedy writes for WSJ Pro Bankruptcy.

Banner Ridge Partners has wrapped up its newest and largest secondary fund with $1 billion, as Preeti Singh reports for WSJ Pro Private Equity. Preeti spoke to co-founder Anthony Cusano about the fundraising process and the challenges and opportunities that he sees ahead for secondary investors.

Big Number

61%

The percentage of nearly 100 portfolio companies that disclosed their Scope 1 and Scope 2 greenhouse-gas emissions in 2020, up from just 1% in 2018, according to research from general partners and limited partners that was facilitated by Boston Consulting Group.

Deals

Blackstone Inc. is buying a majority stake in Spanx Inc., becoming the first outsider to put money into a company that shook up women's shapewear, Miriam Gottfried reports for The Wall Street Journal. The deal values Spanx at $1.2 billion, the companies said. Spanx founder Sara Blakely will maintain a significant stake in the company and will continue to oversee operations. She will become the company's executive chairwoman when the deal closes.

Alternative investment firm King Street Capital Management, LP and Canadian investor Alberta Investment Management Corporation have teamed up with an unnamed sovereign-wealth fund to launch a joint venture that will acquire and develop production studios alongside private-equity-backed East End Studios. The platform will target investments in existing facilities along with new development or redevelopment opportunities, according to a press release. Its initial projects include three locations in the greater Los Angeles area with a total capitalization of more than $500 million, the press release stated.

Summit Partners has agreed to lead a $625 million investment in Invicti Security, a technology company that helps businesses and public organizations test and secure web applications. Turn/River Capital, which initially invested in the company back in 2017, will remain a significant shareholder, according to a press release.

Carlyle Group has led a strategic growth investment of up to $430 million in Saama Technologies Inc. and will take a majority stake in the cloud-based healthcare technology company, which offers data management and analytics technology used for clinical trials. A group of firms that co-invested in the deal alongside Carlyle includes healthcare-focused venture investors Amgen Ventures, Intermountain Ventures, Merck Global Health Innovation Fund, McKesson Ventures, Northpond Ventures, Pfizer Ventures, and Population Health Partners, according to a news release.

Trilantic North America has invested in WebFX, a technology enabled digital marketing services provider. Trilantic is funding the investment out of its Trilantic Capital Partners VI (North America) LP, which closed in 2019 at $2.75 billion.

A group including private-equity-backed Zayo Group LLC is trying to buy broadband network owner Uniti Group Inc. and its primary client, Windstream Holdings II LLC, Cara Lombardo and Miriam Gottfried report for The Wall Street Journal, citing people familiar with the matter.

SoftBank-backed Flock Freight raised $215 million in a new funding round supporting its load-matching technology to help shippers pool their goods on trucks to bypass freight hubs, Lydia O'Neal writes for The Wall Street Journal. The latest round values the startup at $1.3 billion and brings total funding for the company to $399 million.

Insight Partners has led a $50 million series C growth funding round for enterprise technology company Honeycomb, bringing the total amount of funding the company has raised to date to $96.9 milion. Other investors in the round include existing backers Scale Venture Partners, Headline (formerly e.ventures), Storm Ventures, Industry Ventures, and NextWorld Capital.

Lower midmarket private-equity firm Silver Oak Services Partners has recapitalized Alpharetta, Ga.-based Summit Housing, which offers cloud hosting services for software and accounting applications to small and medium businesses.

Exits

ICV Partners has sold Outpatient Imaging Affiliates to Cranemere Group, a London-based holding company focused on long term investments. ICV originally acquired Nashville-based Outpatient Imaging, which operates 56 imaging centers across 18 markets, back in 2018.

Funds

EQT said it is targeting â‚¬4 billion, the equivalent of $4.65 billion, for EQT Future Fund, an impact fund with a longer lifespan than typical funds. The fund could hold companies for eight to 10 years, according to Chief Executive and Managing Partner Christian Sinding. "And that means that we can take a longer time perspective on the investments and drive deeper transformation and go into companies where you need a different timeline fit," Mr. Sinding told WSJ Pro Private Equity's Preeti Singh.

Blackstone Inc. is preparing its next flagship fund and could seek as much as $30 billion for the offering, Sabrina Willmer reports for Bloomberg. A $30 billion fund would rank the offering as the largest private-equity fund raised by a standalone firm.

Sagard Holdings Inc. said its credit unit is launching a new senior loan fund that will be led by Dev Gopalan, who has joined the firm as a partner and portfolio manager. Mr. Gopalan previously served as chief executive of specialty finance company Angel Island Capital. Sagard's new senior loan strategy will focus on first lien lending to non-sponsor owned North American companies with $50 million or less in earnings before interest, tax, deprecation and amortization, according to a news release.

People

Edison Partners announced a series of promotions, including Gregg Michaelson to general partner and Jennifer Lee to partner. The firm also promoted Joe Giquinto to chief financial officer.

Evercore said it has hired Thomas Sabatier as vice president in its private capital advisory group, where he will advise on secondary transactions out of the firm's London office. Mr. Sabatier joins from secondary intermediary and placement firm Triago, where he was a principal.

Industry News

Many years ago, back when I was a cub reporter, I remember executives from Partners Group telling me they hated the firm being referred to as a "fund of funds manager" so much that they banned references to it as a fund of funds manager among their employees. These days, as Miriam Gottfried reports for the Journal, the new forbidden word at the firm is "deal".

China Evergrande Group called off plans to sell a majority stake in its property-management unit for the equivalent of $2.6 billion, a major setback in the real-estate giant's attempts to ease its liquidity crunch, Serena Ng writes for the Journal.
